Citation: Chen, Q., Chen, Y., Liu, D., Shi, C., Wu, Y., & Qu, H. (2016). Peakvizor: Visual analytics of peaks in video clickstreams from massive open online courses. IEEE transactions on visualization and computer graphics, 22(10), 2315-2330.
Description: This study explores students' clickstream data of videos in the context of MOOCs. The study uses an algorithm to identify peaks of interactions from students, to make sense out of this.
CommentsCVG: Describes relevant related work in Glyphs, visualization of clickstream data and say they are "inspired" by this work. However, there is no connection to these elements in the discussion
CommentsCET: No clear connection with any learning theory.

Citation: Dyckhoff, A. L., Zielke, D., Bültmann, M., Chatti, M. A., & Schroeder, U. (2012). Design and implementation of a learning analytics toolkit for teachers. Educational Technology & Society, 15(3), 58-76.
Description: Describes eLAT, a learning analytics dashboard, for teachers to explore how students use certain learning objects

Citation: Atapattu, T., Falkner, K., & Tarmazdi, H. (2016). Topic-wise classification of MOOC discussions: A visual analytics approach. In Proceedings of the 9th International conference on Educational Data Mining (EDM), Raleigh, NC, USA.
Description: Dashboard application to visualize discussion forums
CommentsCVG: Summarizes existing work on visualization of MOOC and forums data. Informs the visualization using literature in visual analytics. Does not discusses findings using visualization literature
CommentsCET: Uses existing literature to make the case for understanding students' discourse in MOOC forums in order to better understand "learners' cognitive processes". Briefly connects the discussion with existing literature (one reference)

Citation: Lockyer, L., Heathcote, E., & Dawson, S. (2013). Informing pedagogical action: Aligning learning analytics with learning design. American Behavioral Scientist, 57(10), 1439-1459.
Description: This paper proposes a connection between learning design and learning analytics.  The paper then demonstrates this connection with the SNAPP visualization tool, a graph-based viz for interactions in discussion forum
CommentsCVG: The paper presents a summary of visualizations and learning analytics tools in Table I, and discusses Social network diagrams in more detail to inform their design and interpretation of the visualizations
CommentsCET:
The paper advocates for a strong connection between learning analytics and learning design "any user interaction behavior must be analyzed in the specific education context such as the learning design 
and course modality. An understanding of the learning design context is imperative for establishing accurate predictive models alongside pedagogical recommendations. "
HtmlText:

Citation: Chen, Y., Chen, Q., Zhao, M., Boyer, S., Veeramachaneni, K., & Qu, H. (2016, October). Description: Visual analytics system for understanding students' reasons for dropping out MOOCs

Citation: Thompson, K., Ashe, D., Carvalho, L., Goodyear, P., Kelly, N., & Parisio, M. (2013). Processing and visualizing data in complex learning environments. American Behavioral Scientist, 57(10), 1401-1420.
Description: This paper proposes how to use visual learning analytics using two case studies to demonstrate it.
CommentsCVG: The paper reviews existing approaches to visualize this type of data and uses this background information to inform their design and interpretation. However, this connection with existing literature is not present on the discussion
CommentsCET: While this study uses an analytical framework that is informed by several areas listed in the paper, the connection to educational theories is limited and not explicit.
Venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics

Citation: Schwab, M., Strobelt, H., Tompkin, J., Fredericks, C., Huff, C., Higgins, D., ... & Pfister, H. (2017). booc. io: An Education System with Hierarchical Concept Maps and Dynamic Non-linear Learning Plans. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 23(1), 571-580.

Description: The purpose of this study is to create a visualization tool of content, that could help both instructors and students to visualize how the content of a given course should be learned

CVG: The paper analyzes existing approaches for knowledge visualization to inform the design, but there is no connection to these elements in the discussion

CET: The paper mentions self-guided learning and personalized learning, but does not expand on the theory nor does it guide the research component using these as frameworks.



Citation: Gómez-Aguilar, D. A., Hernández-García, Á., García-Peñalvo, F. J., & Therón, R. (2015). Tap into visual analysis of customization of grouping of activities in eLearning. Computers in Human Behavior, 47, 60-67.

Description: This paper aims at identifying a relationship between students' behavior and performance using a learning analytics tool

CVG: The paper summarizes existing visualization approaches to inform their design. However, there is no discussion of the results under the lens of the specific visualizations

CET: Presents a background in learning analytics and the types of interactions that can take place, but does not connect these to an educational theory

Citation: Schreurs, B., Teplovs, C., Ferguson, R., De Laat, M., & Buckingham Shum, S. (2013, April). Visualizing social learning ties by type and topic: rationale and concept demonstrator. In Proceedings of the Third International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge (pp. 33-37). ACM.
Description: Describes a tool called Network Awareness Tool to visualize informal learning networks
CommentsCVG: Describes network visualization concepts to inform the design of the tool
CommentsCET: Describes networked learning as the theory that guides their research. Discusses the output using this theory, but there are not explicit findings to discuss.

CET: Describes networked learning as the theory that guides their research. Discusses the output using this theory, but there are not explicit findings to discuss.



Citation: Kump, B., Seifert, C., Beham, G., Lindstaedt, S. N., & Ley, T. (2012, April). Seeing what the system thinks you know: visualizing evidence in an open learner model. In Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge (pp. 153-157). ACM.

Description: Presents a tool that integrates the learner model and information visualization for the identification of knowledge indicating events (KIE)

CVG: Informs the design comparing results from previous studies in the visualization of tree structures. No discussion of the results under the lens of these findings

CET: Introduces the concept of knowledge indicating events (KIE) as "naturally ocurring user actions that are interpreted as evidences for a user's knowledge state, and informs the design on the structure of the open learner model and the KIE. No discussion of findings under existing literature



Citation: Hillaire, G., Rappolt-Schlichtmann, G., & Ducharme, K. (2016). Prototyping Visual Learning Analytics Guided by an Educational Theory Informed Goal. Journal of Learning Analytics, 3(3), 115-142.

Description: The paper proposes a methodology to develop visual learning analytics, and demonstrated it using a case study. The scores used for this paper correspond to the case study that explored the visualization of students' emotions.

CVG: Connects with background on data visualization to inform their design of the tool. Does not discuss the results using this literature

CET: Discusses the role of emotions in learning connecting with existing literature, and informs the visualization tool using this background. Does not discuss the findings under these theories

Citation: Beheshitha, S. S., Hatala, M., Gaševi?, D., & Joksimovi?, S. (2016, April). The role of achievement goal orientations when studying effect of learning analytics visualizations. In Proceedings of the Sixth International Conference on Learning Analytics & Knowledge (pp. 54-63). ACM.

CommentsCET: Discusses achievement goal orientation (AGO), and collaborative learning. Both elements are brought back in the discussion section. However, there is no clear connection to the actual visualizations.

Citation: Fu, S., Zhao, J., Cui, W., & Qu, H. (2017). Visual Analysis of MOOC Forums with iForum. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 23(1), 201-210.

CommentsCET: The paper does not make connection between the proposed work and the educational theories. Instead, just mentions that forums are an important interaction tool in MOOCs
